tions. Many thousands of hours of programming have been prepared for the
NAEB Radio Network by the broadcasting systems of several foreign countries*
This has enabled listeners in this country to learn more about other lands,
fostering deeper understanding. The NAEB has, in exchange, provided programs
for use overseas, thereby increasing the world*s knowledge of our cultural and
educational accomplishments and background. We also receive programs from
other programming agencies in this country (as discussed in the Network sec¬
tion of this report), such as the American Foundation for the Blind, which pro¬
vide a wider audience for the important programs which many of these organiza¬
tions produce.
